title: Drag Queen praises Naga Munchetty on BBC Breakfast after Trump racism row
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Naga Munchetty was praised by a drag queen this morning after a complaint against the presenter was overturned following her comments over Donald Trump’s racist tweets.

Amrou Al-Kadhi voiced their support for the presenter during an appearance on the programme.

‘Naga I just want to say I’m so, so excited to be here with you,’ the performer said. ‘And all people of colour were standing alongside you the past week.

Drag Queen Amrou Al-Kadhi prasied Naga Munchetty for fighting racism after she criticised Donald Trump on air (Picture: BBC)

‘Us sisters have to stick together,’ they continued. ‘And it’s never, never biased to call out racism. So it’s a real honour to be here with you today.’

Remaining notoriously tight-lipped, the anchorwoman didn’t comment on the row, but simply thanked Al-Kadhi ‘for your thoughts’.

Munchetty was originally ruled to have broken BBC guidelines by commenting on the US President’s tweets on July 17, but after widespread criticism from the public and her peers (including even Piers Morgan) the decision was reversed by the channel’s Director-General, Tony Hall.

Naga fired back at Donald’ Trump’s tweet telling his opponents to ‘go back home’ (Picture: BBC)

‘I don’t think Naga’s words were sufficient to merit a partial uphold of the complaint around the comments she made,’ he told staff after backtracking on the ruling.

We haven’t had a direct response from the presenter about the row or its backlash yet, but she certainly looked happy after posting a picture to social media after it was announced she would be returning to work.

If you want to catch up with all the controversy, we’ve compiled a handy guide explaining exactly what went on and why the BBC reversed its initial decision.

BBC Breakfast airs weekdays from 6am on BBC One.
